TCalc: Telescope-Calculator
  • Tcalc
  • Functions
  • age_eye
Edit this page

Tcalc¶

Classes for handling telescope and eyepiece properties.

class tcalc.barlow_lens(barlow=2)¶

Class representing a single Barlow lense :param barlow: the Barlow factor, default is 2 :type barlow: float greater than 1

class tcalc.eyepiece(f_e, fov_e=50)¶

Class representing a single eyepiece :param f_e: focal length of the eyepiece in mm :param fov: field of view of the eyepiece in degrees. Defaults to 50 degrees.

class tcalc.focal_reducer(P_reducer)¶

Class representing a single focal reducer :param P_reducer: the power of the focal reducer :type P_reducer: float between 0 and 1

class tcalc.telescope(D_o, f_o, user_D_eye=None, user_age=None)¶

Class representing a telescope :param D_o: the size of the telescope opening in mm :param flenght: focal length of the telescope in mm :param user_D_eye: diameter of telescope user’s eye in mm. Default is 7 mm. :param user_age: age of the telescope user. Will be used to compute user_D_eye if none is specified.

add_eyepiece(piece, id=None, select=True)¶

Attach an eyepiece to the telescope class The telescope class can have multiple eyepieces associated with it, this method allows you to add a single eyepiece object to the list. :param piece: the eyepiece object to add :type piece: eyepiece class instance :param id: the name to give the eyepiece - it will be identified by this name :type id: string :param when selecting and analyzing eyepiece configurations. If unspecified: :param it will be set to a number.: :param select: if True (default) the added eyepiece will be selected by calling the select_eyepiece method. :type select: bool

Returns

None

add_optic(optic, id=None, select=True)¶

Attach an optical part to the telescope class The telescope class can have multiple optical parts (focal reducers and Barlow lenses) associated with it, this method allows you to add a single part to the list. :param optic: the optical part object to add :type optic: focal_reducer or barlow_lens class instance :param id: the name to give the part - it will be identified by this name :type id: string :param when selecting and analyzing optical configurations. If unspecified: :param it will be set to a number.: :param select: if True (default) the added optical part will be selected by calling the select_eyepiece method. :type select: bool

Returns

None

change_user_age(new_age)¶

Update the age of the user and the corresponding eye size :param new_age: the age of the user :type new_age: float > 0

Returns

None

list_eyepiece()¶

List the eyepieces and other optics availabe to the telescope :param None:

Returns

Prints out a list of eyepiece objects and the

current eyepiece being used.

say_configuration()¶

List properties of the telescope eyepiece pair :param None:

Returns

Writes out the properties of the telescope

select_eyepiece(id=None)¶

Set the current eyepiece :param id: The id of the eyepiece to include. Default is None, which selects no eyepiece

Returns

None

select_optic(id=None)¶

Set the current optical part :param id: The id of the optical part to include. Default is None, which selects no optical part

Returns

None

show_eyepiece_limits()¶

Plots the eyepiece limits for a telescope-eyepiece pair according to user’s age and pupil diameter :param None:

Returns

Plot of minimum achievable magnification as a function of pupil’s diameter which varies according to user’s age. Also, plots the power of the current selected eyepice.

show_magnification_limits()¶

Plots the magnification limits for a telescope-eyepiece pair according to user’s age :param None:

Returns

Plot of maximum achievable magnification as a function of pupil’s diameter which varies according to user’s age. Also, plots the magnification strength’s of the current selected eyepice.

show_resolving_power(seeing=2.5)¶

Plots the resolution performance of the telescope for a specific seeing value :param seeing: Seeing factor of sky. Default to 2.5 :type seeing: float

Returns

A plot depicting variation of chromatic resolution or simply the resolution at different wavelengths with respect to Dawes Limit and Limit due to seeing
